    Small Molecules Selectively Targeting Sigma-1 Receptor for the Treatment of Neurological Diseases

    • Na Ye*
      Na Ye

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    The sigma-1 (σ1) receptor, an enigmatic protein originally classified as an opioid receptor subtype, is now understood to possess unique structural and functional features of its own and play critical roles to widely impact signaling transduction by interacting with receptors, ion channels, lipids, and kinases. The σ1 receptor is implicated in modulating learning, memory, emotion, sensory systems, neuronal development, and cognition and accordingly is now an actively pursued drug target for various neurological and neuropsychiatric disorders. Evaluation of the five selective σ1 receptor drug candidates (pridopidine, ANAVEX2-73, SA4503, S1RA, and T-817MA) that have entered clinical trials has shown that reaching clinical approval remains an evasive and important goal. This review provides up-to-date information on the selective targeting of σ1 receptors, including their history, function, reported crystal structures, and roles in neurological diseases, as well as a useful collation of new chemical entities as σ1 selective orthosteric ligands or allosteric modulators.

     Note

    Due to production error, this paper was published on October 28, 2020, with part of Table 1 missing. The corrected version was reposted on October 29, 2020.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The sigma-1 (σ1) receptor is encoded by the sigma-1 gene and was originally classified as an opioid receptor subtype, but subsequent research has illuminated a vast and unique array of structural and functional features distinct among other mammalian transmembrane proteins. It is predominately localized to the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) membrane, specifically the ER–mitochondria interface known as the mitochondria-associated membrane (MAM); however, upon ligand-directed activation, the σ1 receptor can translocate to multiple cellular destinations including the plasma membrane (PM) and nuclear envelope.(1) The σ1 receptor is expressed in both the central nervous system (CNS) and peripheral tissues and exhibits complex functions such as regulating mitochondrial functions and autophagy.(2−5) Interest in the σ1 receptor and its functions has increased in recent years, coinciding with numerous new discoveries about this previously understudied protein (Figure 1). In the CNS, the σ1 receptor is involved in neuroprotection, neuroinflammation, neurotransmission, and neuroplasticity and thus is functionally associated with advanced brain functions such as memory, cognition, mood, pain, and neurodegeneration. Unsurprisingly, the σ1 receptor has become an actively pursued drug target for several CNS disorders, including, but not limited to, neurodegenerative diseases, pain, stroke, retinal degenerations, and depression. So far, five selective σ1 receptor ligands have been advanced into human phase 2/3 clinical trials. ANAVEX2-73, a σ1 agonist, is currently under phase 2/3 investigation for Rett syndrome and early stage Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Pridopidine is being investigated in a phase 2 study for Levodopa-induced dyskinesia, and a phase 3 study for early stage Huntington’s disease (HD). The current clinical study of selective σ1 receptor ligands is a promising trend, and the resultant data should deliver additional guidance for new σ1 receptor drug candidates reaching clinical phase programs. Herein, this review will introduce the history, functions, and roles of σ1 receptors in various human CNS diseases and highlight the ongoing clinical efforts and recent advances in developing selective σ1 receptor orthosteric ligands and allosteric modulators from a medicinal chemistry perspective.

    2. The History of Sigma-1 Receptor

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The sigma (σ) receptor was classified as the σ subtype of opioid receptors by Martin(6) in 1976 and was initially thought to mediate psychotomimetic effects of morphine and its analogues (Figure 2). However, Su and colleagues(7) in 1982 demonstrated that this “σ opioid receptor” differed from other known opioid receptors due to its low affinity for naltrexone, a nonselective high-affinity opioid receptor antagonist, and subsequent studies with enantiomers of [3H]-N-allylnormetazocine showed that the “σ opioid receptor” exhibited a preference for the (+)-enantiomer, while true opioid receptors bind with high affinity only to the (−)-enantiomer.(8) The σ1 receptor was also suggested to be a subunit containing the phencyclidine (PCP) binding site of N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptors (PCP/NMDA) for a short time period owing to the polypharmacology of certain ligands (e.g., SKF-10047), whose pharmacological effects are mediated not only via σ receptors but also NMDA receptors or kappa opioid receptors.(9) The σ receptors were subsequently recognized to form an independent receptor family based on their unique structures and functions. In 1992, two distinct subtypes of σ receptors were classified by their pharmacological profiles: sigma-1 (σ1) and sigma-2 (σ2) receptors,(10,11) which are not genetically related to each other and differentiated by their molecular weight, anatomical, and cellular distribution and ligand binding profiles.(12)
    It was not until 1996 that structural information about the σ1 receptor was available when the receptor was first cloned from guinea pig liver(13) and subsequently in human cell lines;(14) whereas the σ2 receptor was not structurally identified until 2017, previously being proposed as the progesterone receptor membrane component 1 (PGRMC1) protein and more recently termed transmembrane protein-97 (TMEM97) using a chemical biology approach.(15) The σ1 receptor is a 24 kD molecular mass protein of 223 amino acids, and the σ2 receptor is known as a transmembrane protein with a molecular weight ranging from 18 to 21.5 kDa.(10) The amino acid sequence indicates that the σ1 receptor shares no significant homology with any other known mammalian transmembrane receptors (e.g., G protein-coupled receptors or ligand-gated ion channels). It was initially recognized as containing a sole transmembrane helix, but later, a two-pass transmembrane model was widely adopted as the basis for molecular modeling studies.(13) In 2003, the first sigma-1 knockout (KO) mouse model was generated with the aid of homologous recombination techniques by Langa and colleagues,(16) which rendered a powerful tool to investigate the roles of σ1 receptor in normal and pathological physiology.
    Functionally, the σ1 receptor is understood as a Ca2+-sensitive and ligand-operated receptor chaperone primarily localized at mitochondrion-associated ER membranes. In addition to the regulation of Ca2+ flux from the ER, either directly or via chaperone interactions with the inositol triphosphate receptor (InsP3-R), σ1 receptors are known to at least partly modulate neurotransmitter release, inflammation, cell survival including autophagy, and synaptogenesis.(17) Nevertheless, the σ2 receptor is distributed and able to translocate among the endoplasmic reticulum, lysosomes, and mitochondria, resulting in a wide range of cellular actions including the release of intracellular Ca2+, dopaminergic transmission, and neuroregeneration as well as cholesterol homeostasis, thereby involving in the pathogenesis of cancer and neurological disorders.(10) Regardless of these unique features of the σ1 receptor compared to traditional receptors, the International Union of Basic and Clinical Pharmacology (IUPHAR) included the σ1 receptor in its list of receptors as sigma nonopioid intracellular receptor 1 in 2013,(18) even though it may not fit the classical definition of a receptor due to the lack of evidence for coupling through conventional signaling pathways. However, the ligand-operated nature of the σ1 receptor and the identification of ligands with varying modes of action (e.g., agonists, antagonists, and allosteric modulators) support the receptor classification.
    In 2016, the first crystal structures of the full-length human σ1 receptor were successfully solved in a cocomplex with two different ligands, PD144418 and 4-IBP.(19) Later in 2018, the cocrystal structures of the σ1 receptor bound to haloperidol, NE-100, and (+)-pentazocine were also disclosed.(20) As shown in Figure 3, the σ1 receptor has been crystallized as a homotrimer comprising three tightly associated protomers (Figure 3A), each of which contains only a single transmembrane domain, consistent with the earliest structural consensus rather than the two-pass models that followed. The high affinity and selective σ1 receptor antagonist PD144418 and σ1 receptor agonist (+)-pentazocine are deeply buried and occluded in the binding pocket from the solvent, and each ligand interacts with the receptor through an electrostatic interaction between GLU172 and the basic nitrogen presented in most σ1 receptor ligands and van der Waals interactions of the hydrophobic binding pocket including residues VAL84, TRP89, MET93, TYR103, LEU105, PHE107, ILE124, and TRP164 (Figure 3B).(21)

    3. Functional Implications of the Sigma-1 Receptor in Neurological Diseases

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The σ1 receptor remains an enigmatic protein because a preferential endogenous ligand has yet to be conclusively identified, even though steroids [e.g., progesterone, dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA), 25-hydroxycholesterol],(22) the hallucinogen N,N-dimethyltryptamine (DMT),(23) and sphingolipids d-erythro-sphingosine(24) and ceramides(25) have been postulated to act as endogenous ligands. As shown in Figure 4, the σ1 receptor is normally in complex with the chaperone protein BiP (binding immunoglobulin protein), which plays a critical role in protein folding and prevents the inactive state σ1 receptor from translocation (Figure 4). Specific activation of the σ1 receptor (e.g., agonist binding) induces its dissociation from BiP, leading to receptor translocation to different organelle membranes, including endoplasmic reticulum membranes, nuclear membranes, mitochondrial membranes, plasma membranes, cytosolic vesicles, and even the extracellular space.(1,17) Current research suggests an absence of an intrinsic system for signal transduction upon σ1 receptor activation. Alternatively, σ1 receptor activation is generally believed to modulate an array of targets, including receptors, ion channels, lipids, kinases, and other signaling proteins primarily via translocation and protein–protein interactions. These interactions then modulate or fine-tune the partner protein’s associated cellular second messenger systems commonly involved in intracellular calcium signaling and inositol triphosphate (IP3) turnover. There are at least 49 proteins with high divergence in sequence and structure (Figure 4), which have been reported to interact with the σ1 receptor.(12,21) Because of the promiscuous nature of its effects on consensus downstream signaling pathways, the σ1 receptor has unsurprisingly been shown to play a role in maintaining the balance of glutamatergic, cholinergic, dopaminergic, serotoninergic, norepinephrinergic, and GABAergic systems in the brain.(26) However, the exact characteristics and extent of σ1 receptor interactions and influence in each pathway remain to be elucidated.
    The σ1 receptor is widely distributed throughout the brain with the highest densities found in the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus, facial nucleus, thalamic, and hypothalamic nuclei, and moderate densities in the striatum, cerebellum, dorsal raphe nucleus (DRN), and locus coeruleus.(27,28) Thus, drug discovery campaigns should thoroughly interrogate neural circuit-specific biological effects and work to ensure CNS penetrability and sufficient target exposure. Current studies on the σ1 receptor provide a rationale that selective modulation may alleviate or improve a variety of neurological and neuropsychiatric diseases including neurodegenerative disorders, stroke, depression, pain, seizure, and schizophrenia.

    3.1. Neurodegenerative Disorders

    Alterations in the function of σ1 receptors have been associated with observed neurodegenerative disease pathologies, attracting attention to this target for the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases including AD, Parkinson’s disease (PD), and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).(29) Broadly, σ1 receptor dysfunction may worsen the progression of neurodegenerative diseases, while σ1 receptor activation elicits potent neuroprotective effects, promotes neuronal survival, and restores neuronal plasticity to slow disease progression via mechanisms including the modulation of calcium homeostasis and glutamate activities, attenuation of oxidative and nitrosative stress, maintenance of ER and mitochondrial integrity, and attenuation of inflammation.(21,29−32)

    3.1.1. Alzheimer’s Disease

    Amyloid beta peptide (Aβ) is generated intracellularly at the MAM domain and may influence the function of the ER, mitochondria, and MAM, where the σ1 receptor is densely located, suggesting a possible correlation between the σ1 receptor and the pathogenesis of AD.(33) Certain genetic interactions between the σ1 receptor and apolipoprotein E (APOE), a commonly recognized genetic risk factor of late-onset AD, were found to synergistically influence AD severity across multiple populations.(34) Notably, in vivo brain imaging studies with [11C]SA4503 have revealed a reduced density of σ1 receptor in the frontal, temporal, and occipital lobes, cerebellum, and thalamus of early stage AD patients.(35) Consistent with this observation, σ1 receptor knockdown destabilizes neuronal mushroom spines whose loss may underlie memory defects in animal models of AD.(36) Moreover, both pharmacological inactivation of the σ1 receptor with the antagonist NE-100 and knockout of the σ1 receptor facilitate amyloid (Aβ25–35) toxicity, thereby inducing learning impairment, oxidative stress, and BDNF alteration in AD animal models.(37) These results suggest a role for the σ1 receptor in AD pathology and as a potential disease-modifying drug target.
    In preclinical studies, treatment with σ1 receptor agonists (e.g., igmesine, pridopidine, AF710B, ANAVEX2-73, PRE-084) and positive allosteric modulators (e.g., OZP002) has resulted in increased cognition, memory improvement, antiamnesic effects, neuroprotection, and antidepressant-like effects. The underling mechanisms may include the modulation of glutamate release and calcium homeostasis, as well as the functional modulation of potassium channels and NMDA, neuroplasticity, and the reduction of oxidative stress.(1,21,28,38,39) The potential therapeutic effects of σ1 receptor agonists or positive modulators in AD are further supported by studies in which direct activation of σ1 receptors produced alterations in NMDA receptor expression, increased synaptic transmission, and plasticity of NMDA receptor via small-conductance calcium-activated K+ (SK) channels(40) and potentiated NMDA-induced neuronal firing in the CA3 region of the hippocampus.(41) Additionally, van Waarde et al.(38) summarized the effects of several σ1 receptor agonists on cognitive performance in various animal models, including cholinergic deficits, Aβ25–35 peptide induced pathology, aging-induced memory loss, drug-induced glutamatergic, serotonergic, or calcium channel deficits and neurodegeneration caused by neurotoxicity, in which applications of σ1 receptor selective antagonists (e.g., BD-1047, NE-100) blocked the effect, suggesting σ1 receptor-dependent activity.(21,29)
    Furthermore, the σ1 receptor functionally interacts with presenilin 1 (PS1) and presenilin 2 (PS2), which are implicated in the pathological process of AD. Knockout of PS1, PS2, or PS1/2 in hippocampal neurons results in mushroom spine aberrations, which may disrupt tonic Ca2+ release from the ER and detrimentally increase the concentration of calcium in the ER.(36,42) Similarly, inactivation of PS1, PS2, or PS1/2 in the mouse forebrain impacts cognition and synaptic plasticity.(43) Instead, σ1 receptor agonists (e.g., AF710B, pridopidine) decrease ER calcium in hippocampal neurons by enhancing ER calcium leakage in the ER membrane, thereby reducing the potentially pathological accumulation and aggregation of Aβ42.(36,44)

    3.1.2. Parkinson’s Disease

    The σ1 receptor is expressed in both astrocytes and dopaminergic neurons of the substantia nigra and striatum.(45) Positron emission tomography (PET) studies have demonstrated that expression of the σ1 receptor was decreased in the brains of early stage PD patients.(46)Sigma-1 KO mice experienced an increase in age-related loss of dopaminergic neurons and deficits in motor coordination while also displaying increased aggregation and phosphorylation of α-synuclein (αSyn).(47) Moreover, sigma-1 knockdown Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells were sensitized to apoptosis induced by dopamine at physiological concentrations (lower than 10 μM) that was likely attributed to the activation of NF-κB and subsequent downregulation of Bcl-2.(48) The σ1 receptor also has been implicated in the regulation of neuroinflammation. It was shown that activation of σ1 receptor inhibited microglia-mediated neuroinflammation and protected dopaminergic neurons.(32,49) These findings indicate that the σ1 receptor may play a role in the pathological development of PD.
    σ1 receptor agonists were found to modulate dopaminergic neurotransmission. Activation of the σ1 receptor by cocaine inhibits D2 receptor-mediated signaling via σ1–D2 receptor heteromers,(50) whereas it disrupts the H3 receptor-mediated brake on D1 receptor signaling via σ1–D1–H3 receptor complexes.(51) A recent study illustrated that σ1 receptor agonists were characterized as neuroprotective and neurorestorative due to the activation of endogenous defense and plasticity mechanisms in PD models.(45) Dosing of the σ1 receptor agonist PRE084 at 0.3 mg/kg/day in a preclinical chronic dosing paradigm was shown to produce both histological and behavioral improvements in the 6-hydroxydopamine (6-OHDA)-lesioned PD model, including a modest recovery of dopamine levels, increased dopaminergic fiber densities, the upregulation of multiple neurotrophic factors [brain derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) and glial cell derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF)], and improvement in spontaneous forelimb use.(45) In the same study, it was found that PRE084 also significantly attenuated the number of CD68-positive microglia and macrophages induced by 6-OHDA lesions.(45) In another preclinical model, chronic application of PRE084 to an inducible dicer conditional KO mouse model of PD attenuated the development of motor impairments and dopaminergic neuron death.(11) Thus, the targeting of σ1 receptors with selective chemical probes may further illuminate the complex network of dopaminergic and neuroinflammatory factors underlying PD, potentially leading to therapeutic development.

    3.1.3. Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)

    In the CNS, one location where σ1 receptors are enriched is in the brain and spinal cord motor neurons (MNs). Dysfunctional σ1 receptors have been shown to exacerbate the pathological development of ALS.(52) Key mutations in the σ1 receptor have been found in patients with frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD)-ALS(53) and consanguineous family segregating juvenile ALS,(54) and the overall expression levels of the σ1 receptor was found to be significantly decreased in the lumbar spinal cord of ALS patients.(55) σ1 receptor KO mice also showed locomotor deficits which may be associated with the reduced contacts between mitochondria and ER, ER stress, and calcium dysregulation, which may result in muscle weakness, axonal degeneration, and motor neuron loss.(4,52) Moreover, the MNs of σ1 receptor KO mice showed an increase in firing frequency and a decrease in neuronal longevity in the SOD1G93A mouse model of ALS.(52) shRNA knockdown of σ1 receptor in a MN-like cell line (NSC34) led to aberrant ER and Golgi structural integrity and abnormal calcium signaling.(55) Collectively, these findings support a role for the σ1 receptor in the pathogenesis of ALS or in the severity of ALS symptoms.
    Activation of σ1 receptors ameliorates protein aggregation, increases availability of neuronal growth factors, and protects MNs, thereby slowing disease progression in animal models of ALS.(56) In 2009, it was reported that administration of PRE084 protected spinal cord neurons against glutamate excitotoxicity while it also promoted elongation of neurites in MNs through protein kinase C (PKC) activity in an in vitro organotypic model of excitotoxic lesion.(57) It was later found that PRE084 can increase the expression of GDNF and the σ1 receptor cochaperone BiP and promote MNs survival after spinal root avulsion injury in rats.(58) Navarro et al.(59) additionally confirmed the potential therapeutic effect of PRE084 in an ALS mouse model. They found that daily treatment of PRE084 (0.25 mg/kg, ip) from 8 weeks of age significantly improved spinal MN function (e.g., improvement of locomotor performance, preservation of muscle strength, and reduction of signs of paralysis) and the maintenance of both neuromuscular connections and MNs in the spinal cord.(59) Delayed treatment with PRE084 from 12 weeks of age also significantly improved spinal MN function, locomotion capacity, and overall survival.(59) Importantly, these effects by PRE084 were attributable to σ1 receptor activation due to the parallel administration of the selective σ1 receptor antagonist BD1036, which blocked all beneficial effects in the treatment cohort.(59) Additionally, chronic administration of PRE084 reduced microglial immunoreactivity within the MN environment in the ventral spinal cord. PRE084 may also indirectly modulate NMDA-dependent Ca2+ influx and microglial activation, whereby it is able to significantly slow down the degenerative process of ALS symptoms in the SOD1G93A mouse model of ALS.(59) The potential therapeutic effect of PRE084 was further confirmed by employing another model of spontaneous MN degeneration, not linked to SOD1 mutation,(60) in which chronic administration of PRE084 (0.25 mg/kg, ip) for 8 weeks significantly increased the levels of BDNF in the gray matter and improved MN survival and locomotor performances in wobbler mice.(60)
    Collectively, σ1 receptor ligands may serve as promising disease-modifying agents or part of a multitherapeutic approach in the treatment for neurodegenerative diseases.

    3.2. Stroke

    Increased σ1 receptor expression was observed in penumbra neurons following acute stroke.(61) Following an ischemic stroke, excess glutamate is released, resulting in overactivation of NMDARs, and consequently, leads to calcium overload inside affected neurons. Overloading calcium alters multiple downstream pro-cell death signaling pathways such as the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and mitochondrial damage, resulting in excitotoxic neural damage.(62,63) It is interesting to note that both selective and nonselective σ1 receptor agonists have been shown to decrease glutamate release and block intracellular calcium overload following ischemia in vitro.(64,65) Numerous studies have also confirmed the acute benefits of σ1 receptor agonists in multiple animal models of stroke.(30) Treatment with σ1 receptor agonists (e.g., DTG) at 24 h after onset of ischemia can reduce infarct volume and increase neuronal survival in rat models of stroke.(66,67)
    Modulation of neuroinflammation after stroke is another potential therapeutic intervention for cerebral ischemia.(32) Activation of the σ1 receptor by selective agonists or positive allosteric modulators was shown to inhibit microglia-mediated neuroinflammation and elicit neuroprotection in vitro.(49) σ1 receptor ligands also exert neuroprotective effects against cerebral ischemia. Administration of σ1 receptor agonists after embolic stroke in rats enhanced neuronal survival and attenuated radical species production,(66) while another study showed increased levels of anti-inflammatory cytokines and decreased pro-inflammatory cytokines.(68) Moreover, σ1 receptor activation was shown to modulate brain plasticity and facilitate functional recovery after stroke by enhancing cellular transport of biomolecules required for brain tissue repair.(67,69) Interestingly, one study also reported that the σ1 receptor antagonist S1RA reduced stroke damage, highlighting the nuanced nature of σ1 receptor functionality.(70) Hence, modulation of the σ1 receptor holds promising potential for clinical application as a therapeutic agent for ischemic stroke.

    3.3. Depression

    Many marketed antidepressants, including fluoxetine, sertraline, fluvoxamine, imipramine, and amitriptyline, exhibit a high-to-moderate σ1 receptor affinity with Ki values ranging from 20 to 400 nM (more details in Table 1), although their initial mechanism of antidepression was attributed to either serotonin reuptake inhibition or noradrenaline-reuptake inhibition.(71) It was found that the acute antidepressant effects of fluvoxamine can be blocked by σ1 receptor antagonist BD1047,(72) whereas chronic treatment with antidepressants, including sertraline, citalopram, or paroxetine, can regulate σ1 receptor expression and functional sensitization.(73) Furthermore, σ1 receptor KO mice exhibit a depressive-like phenotype with increased immobility in the forced swimming test.(74) σ1 receptor ligands have also been shown to modulate glutamatergic and serotonergic neuronal activity, leading to antidepressant-like effects. As mentioned earlier, PRE084 showed antidepressant efficacy in AD-relevant models of amnesia. Consistent with that, PRE084 exhibited an antidepressant-like effect in a forced swim test (FST) paradigm in both Albino Swiss and C57BL/6J mice.(75) Importantly, the antidepressant effect of PRE084 could be counteracted by a σ1 receptor antagonist BD1047, but not by a σ2 receptor antagonist SM-21.(75) The selective σ1 receptor agonist SA4503(76) also produces antidepressant-like effects (e.g., agitation, loss of interest, and impaired cognition) in the olfactory bulbectomized (OB) rat model of depression, which may be associated with σ1 receptor-dependent changes in the expression and function of NMDA receptors. Additionally, the σ1 receptor plays an important role in regulating the production and function of BDNF, thereby leading to glutamate release and sustaining antidepressant action.(77) In addition to σ1 receptor agonists, allosteric modulators also exhibit promising, fast-acting antidepressant-like effects, attributed to the stimulation of BDNF production (see more details in section 5.2).(78) Collectively, these findings suggest that the σ1 receptor may serve as a target for the discovery development of novel antidepressant drugs.
    Table 1. Therapeutic Drugs with High Affinity for Sigma-1 Receptor

    3.4. Pain

    σ1 receptors are expressed in pain-modulating tissues and brain regions including the dorsal spinal cord, dorsal root ganglion neurons, the periaqueductal gray matter, rostroventral medulla, and locus coeruleus.(79,80) The expression of σ1 receptors in the spinal cord was found to be upregulated during the induction phase of neuropathic pain in animal models.(81,82) Moreover, knockout of σ1 receptors in mice resulted in an increased mechanical antinociception response to morphine.(83) Collectively, these studies indicate that the σ1 receptor may be involved in the modulation of diverse pain mechanisms.
    Although the σ1 receptor lacks a specified signaling cascade, as a molecular chaperone it can influence the functionality of multiple ion channels and receptors involved in the transmission and amplification of nociceptive signals. The ion channel partners of the σ1 receptor involved in nociception include voltage-gated sodium channels (e.g., Nav1.2, Nav1.4, Nav1.5, Nav1.8), acid-sensing ion channels, voltage-gated potassium channels (e.g., Kv1.2), calcium-activated potassium channels (e.g., SK), voltage-gated calcium channels, and ligand-gated calcium channels (NMDAR).(84) For example, direct activation of spinal cord σ1 receptors potentiates NMDA-evoked spontaneous pain behavior and produces pronociceptive actions under certain altered and pathological conditions.(85) The GPCR partners of the σ1 receptor implicated in nociception include cannabinoid CB1 and μ-opioid (MOR) receptors. A physical interaction between MOR and the σ1 receptor was demonstrated by coimmunoprecipitation experiments in transfected HEK cells. Antagonism of the σ1 receptor (e.g., haloperidol, E-52862) increases opioid receptor signaling and decreases the responsiveness of NMDA receptors, leading to enhanced opioid antinociception and decreased sensory hypersensitivity. σ1 receptor antagonists alone (see more details in S1RA Analogues of section 5.1.2) have been shown to exert antinociceptive effects in preclinical models of inflammatory pain, ischemic pain, and neuropathic pain induced by nerve trauma or chemical injury (e.g., the antineoplastic paclitaxel).(84,86)
    Notably, unlike opioids, σ1 receptor antagonists do not effect normal sensory mechanical and thermal sensitivity thresholds, but they exert antihypersensitive effects in sensitizing conditions and restore nociceptive thresholds back to normal values.(87) Thus, σ1 receptor antagonists are not classical analgesics rather acting as antiallodynic and antihyperalgesic drugs when the system is sensitized following prolonged noxious stimulation or persistent abnormal afferent input (e.g., secondary to nerve injury). Additionally, it has been suggested that σ1 receptor antagonists can be used as an add-on therapy to an opioid regimen to potentiate opioid analgesia and lower the doses of opioids without enhancing opioid-induced adverse effects including tolerance, dependence, or constipation.(88) Thus, σ1 receptor antagonists may increase the therapeutic index of opioids for pain treatment.
    Taken together, σ1 receptor antagonists may represent a promising strategy for the management of various pain conditions including neuropathic, inflammatory, orofacial, visceral, and postoperative pain either as monotherapy or opioid adjuvant therapy.

    4. Clinical Development on Selective Sigma-1 Receptor Ligands

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Because of its uniquely promiscuous binding to numerous pharmacological agents, many clinically used CNS-targeted drugs have moderate to high affinity toward the σ1 receptor, including antipsychotics such as haloperidol that act as a σ1 receptor antagonist, and antidepressants (e.g., fluvoxamine, sertraline, fluoxetine, imipramine), analgesics (e.g., pentazocine), antitussive (e.g. carbetapentane), and anti-Alzheimer’s drugs (e.g., donepezil), which all act as σ1 receptor agonists. Nevertheless, none of them shows σ1 receptor selectivity over their primary therapeutic targets (Table 1).(89) Although the exact therapeutic contribution or extent of contribution of σ1 receptor binding for these drugs remains to be unraveled, available data suggests that their clinical efficacy is partly ascribed to σ1 receptor modulation. Therefore, there are no drugs selectively targeting σ1 receptors yet on the market. Several σ1 receptor ligands, as shown in Figure 5 and Table 2, have successfully entered into later phase clinical studies for many therapeutic areas, especially for neurodegenerative disorders, stroke, and pain, which may further validate the σ1 receptor as a molecular target for the treatment of various human conditions.
    Table 2. Sigma-1 Selective Ligands in Human Clinical Trials
    highest clinic trialconditionsNCT no.study start
    Pridopidine
    phase 3early Huntington diseaseNCT045566562020
    recruiting   
            
    phase 2levodopa-inducedNCT039227112019
    recruitingdyskinesia  
            
    phase 2/3Huntington’s diseaseNCT007240482008
    completed   
            
    phase 3Huntington’s diseaseNCT006652232008
    completed   
    ANAVEX2-73 (Blarcamesine, AVex-73, AE-37)
    phase 2b/3early Alzheimer’s diseaseNCT043149342020
    recruiting NCT037907092018
            
    phase 2/3pediatric patients with Rett syndromeNCT043044822020
    recruiting   
            
    phase 2Rett syndromeNCT039414442019
    recruiting NCT03758924 
            
    phase 2Parkinson’s disease with dementiaNCT037744592018
    recruiting   
            
    phase 2mild to moderate Alzheimer’s diseaseNCT027568582016
    active   
            
    phase 2aAlzheimer’s diseaseNCT022445412014
    completed   
    SA4503 (Cutamesine, AGY94806)
    phase 2major depressive disorderNCT005511092007
    completedischemic strokeNCT006392492008
    S1RA (E-52862, MR309)
    phase 2aoxaliplatin-induced neuropathic pain(108) 2014
    completed   
    T-817MA (Edonerpic Maleate)
    phase 2mild to moderate Alzheimer’s diseaseNCT020799092014
    completed NCT006639362008
            
    phase 2mild cognitive impairmentNCT041914862019
    recruiting   
    Pridopidine (ACR16), developed by Neurosearch, is a selective σ1 receptor ligand (Ki = 81.7 nM) and D2 stabilizer (Ki(D2 (low)) = 17.5 μM; Ki(D2 (high)) = 7.5 μM) aimed at alleviating motor impairments and increasing neuron survival through the alteration dopaminergic transmission and modulation of the σ1 receptor. In 2008, pridopidine advanced into a phase 3 clinical trial (NCT00724048 and NCT00665223) for the symptomatic treatment of Huntington’s disease (HD), but no significant effect was observed in the improvement of voluntary motor function in HD patients.(63,90) Later, pridopidine was found not to improve motor impairment at 26 weeks compared with placebo in a randomized, multicenter, dose-ranging phase 2 study in adults (aged ≥21 years) with Huntington’s disease (NCT02006472), with indications of a potentially strong placebo effect.(91) Recently, pridopidine was investigated in a phase 2 clinical trial (NCT03922711) for the treatment of levodopa-induced dyskinesia in PD patients and a phase 3 clinical trial (NCT04556656) for early stage HD. Additionally, pridopidine was shown to improve fundamental ALS-linked pathologies including reducing mutant SOD1 aggregations in the spinal cord and attenuating neuromuscular junction disruption as well as subsequent muscle wasting in a SOD1G93A animal model through σ1 receptor agonism.(92)
    ANAVEX2-73 (aka blarcamesine, AVex-73, AE-37), developed by Anavex Life Sciences, is a σ1 receptor agonist (IC50 = 0.86 μM) and muscarinic receptor modulator with moderate affinity (M1–M4: IC50 = 3.3–5.2 μM).(93) Chronic dosing of the drug showed marked in vivo neuroprotective activity in AD models.(3,94) The drug also reversed learning deficits in Aβ25–35 injected mice by blockade of Tau hyperphosphorylation and Aβ1–42 generation.(93) In 2014, a phase 1/2 clinical study demonstrated good safety, bioavailability, and tolerability in patients with Alzheimer’s disease (NCT02244541). Phase 2/3 clinical studies in patients with mild to moderate or early Alzheimer’s disease are ongoing (NCT02756858, NCT03790709, and NCT04314934). Additionally, a phase 2 study is ongoing to evaluate its efficacy for cognitive impairment in patients with PD with dementia (PDD) (NCT03774459). Currently, an endeavor is underway to increase clinical indications for ANAVEX2-73 use in Rett syndrome (RTT) and phase 2 studies in patients of 18 years and older with RTT patients for safety, tolerability, and efficacy evaluation (NCT03941444 and NCT03758924) are recruiting patients. In addition, a phase 2/3 study in patients of 5–18 years of age with RTT is also in recruiting (NCT04304482). Preclinically, ANAVEX2-73 was found to positively regulate autophagy, increase proteostasis capacity, and improve protein aggregation-mediated paralysis in Caenorhabditis elegans, indicating the σ1 receptor is a novel autophagy modulator that may direct drug development in conditions ranging from neurodegeneration to dysfunctional autophagy associated disorders.(2)
    SA4503 (aka Cutamesine, AGY94806) is an orally available, potent, and selective σ1 receptor agonist with an IC50 value of 17 nM, 105-fold selectivity over the σ2 receptor (IC50 = 1800 nM), and very low or no affinity toward 36 other receptors, ion channels, and second messenger systems.(95) SA4503 not only decreased the immobility time in the forced swimming test in rats(96) but also ameliorated the depression-like behavioral deficits (e.g., agitation, loss of interest, and impaired cognition) in the olfactory bulbectomized (OB) rat and calcium/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase IV (CaMKIV) null mice.(76,97) In 2008, a phase 2 study of SA4503, given once daily for 8 weeks, was thus initiated to determine safety and efficacy in 150 subjects with major depressive disorder (NCT00551109). However, the trial data and outcome summaries have yet to be disclosed. In preclinical studies, SA4503 can enhance functional recovery after experimental stroke with a dose administration window of up to 48 h post stroke followed by chronic treatment for 28 days. An ascending dose, phase 2a study of SA4503 was thus conducted to evaluate its safety and motor function restoration after acute ischemic stroke and began with 60 patients in 2008 (NCT00639249). Although SA4503 was safe and well tolerated at a high dosage level, no significant improvement was observed in functional end points. Additional studies warrant further investigation on moderate-to-severe stroke patients.(98) Recently, SA4503 was found efficacious in suppressing motor neuron degeneration and symptom progression in in vitro and in vivo amyotrophic lateral sclerosis models.(99) Moreover, it was found to reverse axonal development and rescue dendritic spine abnormalities as well as cognitive dysfunction in an in vivo α-thalassemia X-linked intellectual disability (ATR-X) syndrome models.(100)
    S1RA (MR309; E-52862), developed by Esteve Research and Development, is the only highly potent and selective σ1 receptor antagonist to progress to clinic stages. It has low nanomolar σ1 receptor affinity (Ki = 17 nM)(101) and moderate affinity for the human 5-HT2B receptor (Ki = 328 nM) but with low antagonistic activity (IC50 = 4700 nM). Moreover, it shows high σ1 receptor selectivity over guinea pig and rat σ2 receptor (Ki > 1000 nM) and a panel of 170 additional targets (Ki > 1 μM or % inhibition <50% at 1 μM) including receptors, transporters, ion channels, and enzymes.(87) Preclinical studies reported that S1RA inhibited neuropathic pain, inflammatory hyperalgesia, activity-induced spinal sensitization, and paclitaxel-induced sensory-nerve mitochondrial abnormalities.(5,87,102−106) S1RA displayed good safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetic properties in phase I clinical studies with 175 healthy subjects.(107) Thus, a phase 2a clinical trial of S1RA in European patients (aged 18–80 years) receiving oxaliplatin (OXA) for colorectal cancer treatment was initiated. This trial was designed to assess neuroprotective efficacy in ameliorating OXA-induced peripheral neuropathy (OXAIPN), which was the most prominent toxicity both during and after the completion of chemotherapy, compromising therapeutic outcomes and patients’ functional capacity and quality of life.(108) S1RA showed a potential neuroprotective role in reducing acute OXAIPN (cold pain and motor symptoms) and was well tolerated with high oxaliplatin exposure and chronic cumulative OXAIPN.(108) Finally, in an animal model of focal cerebral ischemia, it was shown that S1RA reduces stroke damage, ameliorates poststroke neurological deficits, and significantly decreases the overexpression of matrix metalloproteinase-9 (MMP-9) and reactive astrogliosis surrounding the infarcted cortex, suggesting that it may hold promising therapeutic potential for treatment of ischemic stroke.(70)
    T-817MA (Edonerpic maleate) is an orally available neurotropic agent developed by Toyama Chemical Co.(109) It attenuates amyloid-β-induced neurotoxicity and memory deficits as well as motor impairment, promotes neurite outgrowth, and preserves hippocampal synapses and spatial memory in tau transgenic mice.(109−113) However, the molecular mechanisms underlying these effects are not fully understood. These effects may be mediated via σ1 receptor activation, interaction with collapsin-response-mediator-protein 2 (CRMP2), delivery of synaptic glutamate AMPA receptors, or modulation of microglial function.(114) Of note, it shows the highest binding to the σ1 receptor among other CNS receptors, with a Ki value of 16 nM.(115) It has advanced into phase 2 clinic trials in patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer’s disease (NCT02079909 and NCT00663936). However, the clinical outcome of phase 2 trials demonstrated that T-817MA at maximal doses showed no efficacy in patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer disease but exhibited gastrointestinal adverse effects (diarrhea and vomiting).(116) Currently, a phase 2 study of T-817MA is ongoing to evaluate its neuroprotective effect on Tau protein phosphorylated at threonine 181 (p-tau 181) in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of patients diagnosed with mild cognitive impairment due to AD or mild AD (NCT04191486).
    Overall, the clinical fate of σ1 selective ligands pridopidine, ANAVEX2-73 and T-817MA, remains uncertain, and the development of SA4503 and S1RA appears to have halted following missed end points. Thus, it is imperative to develop σ1 receptor selective ligands or modulators as pharmacological probes for unraveling the complex nature of the σ1 receptor’s functionality, signaling pathways, and ability to function as a disease modifying target. When surveying other treatment modalities and targets, lessons in patient selection and disease stage qualifications taken from recent clinical trials in AD and other neurological diseases should guide future clinical development attempts.

    5. Small Molecules Selectively Targeting Sigma-1 Receptor

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As mentioned earlier, because the identification of the native endogenous ligand of the σ1 receptor is inconclusive so far, the function of small molecules selectively targeting σ1 receptor (agonist vs antagonist, positive vs negative allosteric modulator) is defined based on the in vitro or in vivo pharmacological effects compared to the phenotype of σ1 receptor KO animals or that of the consensus tool compounds. Generally, activation of the σ1 receptor engenders beneficial effects in stroke,(69,70,80,98) depression and anxiety disorders,(39,71,78) and neurodegenerative disorders including AD, ALS, and PD,(30,31,59) while blocking the σ1 receptor may be useful to treat pain and substance abuse.(81,89) Given the fundamental role of the receptor in neurological diseases, many intensive efforts have been made to develop σ1 receptor selective ligands or modulators. Herein, this review seeks to provide an update on research advances in the development of chemical entities as σ1 receptor selective ligands since 2014 and σ1 receptor allosteric modulators reported to date.

    5.1. Small Molecules as Selective Sigma-1 Orthosteric Ligands

    5.1.1. Pharmacophore Models for Sigma-1 Receptor

    Before the disclosure of the cocrystal structure, pharmacophore models based on the highly conserved orthosteric binding site represent valuable tools for describing certain structural features necessary for receptor binding. Several σ1 receptor pharmacophore models have been developed for the identification of novel potent orthosteric ligands,(117−120) which also show a degree of commonality with σ2 receptor pharmacophores.(121) The first and most basic σ1 receptor pharmacophore model was developed by Glennon and co-workers(117) in 1994 (Figure 6) via investigation of the structure–affinity relationships (SARs) of N-substituted phenyl-2-aminopropanes binding at the proposed σ1 receptor orthosteric site.
    In Glennon’s model, two hydrophobic binding pockets flank a basic amine moiety that acts as a proton donor site and represents the pharmacophoric elements presumed to be important for σ1 receptor binding (Figure 6).(117) An optimal distance for high σ1 receptor binding affinity was defined in the range of 6–10 Å between the amine moiety and the primary hydrophobic pocket and 2.5–3.9 Å between the amine and the secondary hydrophobic pocket.(117) The primary hydrophobic pocket of the σ1 receptor accommodates diverse structural moieties, especially bulky aromatic groups, while the secondary hydrophobic pocket is slightly smaller than the primary hydrophobic pocket and tolerates less lipophilic substituents such as 1,3-dioxane(122) and tetrahydrofuran.(123,124) Additionally, the amine could be of primary, secondary, or tertiary and cyclic or acyclic nature. Since then, many potent and selective σ1 receptor ligands have been identified with similar structural features characterized by Glennon’s model.

    5.1.2. Recent Selective Sigma-1 Receptor Orthosteric Ligands

    Several diversified core scaffolds have been identified in σ1 receptor ligands so far and there appears to be no generally accepted system for classification of such molecules. In 2015, Kassiou and co-workers(125) produced a valuable summary on the development of σ1 receptor ligands up to the year 2014. Thus, this review relies on broad structural similarity and provides a summation of recent advances in σ1 receptor orthosteric ligand discovery and development since 2014.
    5.1.2.1. SA4503 Analogues
    SA4503, a N,N′-disubstituted piperazine with two phenyl moieties separately occupying the two hydrophobic binding pockets in Glennon’s model, is one of the best known σ1 receptor agonists and has advanced into phase 2 clinical trials for the treatment of major depressive disorder and ischemic stroke. SA4503 displays a 4.6 nM and a 63.09 nM binding affinity (Ki) for σ1 and σ2 receptor in guinea pig (gp) brain tissue, respectively.(126) At least four groups have reinvestigated the σ receptor binding activity of SA4503 reporting slight differences in affinity and selectivity (Ki: σ1 = 3.3–4.6 nM; σ1/ σ2 = 13.7–55).(95,127−129) In 2015, Lever et al.(130) prepared two series of SA4503 ether analogues (1–5) with different patterns and types of substituents on the phenethyl fragment (Figure 7). These compounds typically display a broad spectrum of pharmacological action with relatively high σ1 receptor binding affinity and low selectivity over the σ2 receptor, as well as moderate to low DAT and SERT affinity (e.g., 1–5), suggesting that these polyfunctional ligands may be developed as potential medications for treatment of psychostimulant abuse, depression, and anxiety.(130)
    Owing to the flexible spacer between the nitrogen and two hydrophobic binding pockets of the σ1 receptor, the ethyl and propyl linker of SA4503 can be shortened or lengthened. Recently, 2-(hydroxyalkyl) substituted piperazine derivatives (e.g., 6) represent well established σ1 receptor ligands with high affinity but compromised σ1 receptor selectivity (Figure 8).(131,132) Considering the hydrophobic binding pocket also tolerates the cyclic or linear alkyl groups (e.g., PB28 and 7), Wünsch group(131) identified hydroxyethyl derivative 8 as the most potent and selective σ1 receptor ligand by replacement of two phenyl rings of 6 with a cyclohexyl and 2-naphthyl group. 8 binds to σ1 and σ2 receptor from guinea pig brain and rat liver with Ki values of 4.7 and 69 nM, respectively, while it has affinity of 6.8 and 31 nM for σ1 and σ2 receptors from human tumor cell lines RPMI 8226 and RT-4, respectively.(38) Further replacing the phenyl ring of 6 with conformationally restricted spiro-dioxolane provides a nonhydroxyethyl-substituted piperazine 9 with a significantly improved σ1 receptor binding affinity (Ki = 0.74 nM) and selectivity ratio (47-fold).(133)9 exhibits antiopioid effects in reducing both the KOR agonist (−)-U-50,488H and MOR agonist morphine mediated analgesia in radiant heat tail-flick test, suggesting a σ1 receptor agonistic behavior.
    Ring expansion of the hydroxymethyl-substituted piperazine 6 led to 2-substituted homopiperazines (or 1,4-diazepanes) 10–13 with increased σ1 receptor affinity and selectivity.(134,135,)(10−13) were prepared in a chiral-pool synthesis or solid-phase organic synthesis starting from enantiomerically pure (S)- or (R)-configured α-amino acids. SAR studies indicate the configuration at the 2-position of the homopiperazine seems to have no effects on σ1 receptor affinity but a slight effect on σ2 receptor affinity, leading to the R isomers ((R)-10 and (R)-11) with higher selectivity.(134) The 2-substituent can also tolerate a bulky group including benzyl ((S)-12) and isobutyl ((S)-13) groups but with a slight decrease in σ1 receptor affinity.(134,135) Additionally, homopiperazines 10–12 at a concentration of 1 μM show no affinity with PCP/NMDA receptor, indicating their high σ1 receptor/PCP binding site selectivity. Most recently, Zampieri et al.(136) obtained new derivatives with mono- and biheteroaryls linked to homopiperazines through an amide bond. The best results are reached by benzofurane derivative 14 with Ki values of 8.0, 47, and 1600 nM for σ1, σ2, and GluN2b subunits containing NMDA receptors (GluN2b/NMDA), respectively, and 14 is less toxic at 100 μM concentration (viability >100%) against the human pancreatic carcinoma (PANC1) and human neuroblastoma (SH-SY5Y) cell lines and possesses an excellent antioxidant profile with significant radical scavenging capacity for both ABTS and H2O2 with values of 12.71 and 15.89 μg/mL, indicating its potential neuroprotective activity.(136)
    On the basis of the principle that the piperidine basic nitrogen is considered as the positive ionizable site in their own σ1 receptor 3D pharmacophore model,(119) Zampieri and colleagues(137) designed a series of new arylcarboxamide derivatives with the carbonyl oxygen of the acetamide group as the hydrogen bond acceptor. As shown in Figure 9, 15 with nonsubstituted phenyl group and 16 with 4-chloro substituent show the low nanomolar σ1 receptor affinity (21.2 and 13.6 nM, respectively) and good selectivity (Ki(σ2)/Ki(σ1) >140 and >40, respectively). Reversal of the amide group by Zampieri et al.(138) resulted in the discovery of piperidine-4-carboxamide derivatives. Tetrahydroquinoline 17 and its 4-chloro derivative 18 show the most improved σ1 receptor affinity (Ki = 4.6 and 3.7 nM, respectively) and σ1/σ2 selectivity ratio (>435- and 351-fold, respectively) in the series and exhibit very low NMDA inhibition at 1 μM (19% and 34%).(138) Subsequently, they synthesized a second generation of acetamide derivatives with different aliphatic fragments which replaced the aryl group for occupying the primary hydrophobic pocket.(139) Compound 19 displays good σ1 receptor affinity and selectivity with Ki values of 17 and 1117 nM for σ1 and σ2 receptor, respectively. 19 shows low cytotoxic effect in the MTT assay with IC50 values of 33 μM in Panc-1 cells and 88 μM in SH-SY5Y cells. Additionally, Collina and colleagues(140) employed alkylalkenyl groups as the long linker between the primary hydrophobic pocket and piperidine for development of novel σ receptor modulators, thereby providing compound 20 with subnanomolar σ1 affinity (Ki = 0.7 nM) and a good selectivity over σ2 receptor (67 ratio).
    Conformational restriction of flexible ligands is a widely used strategy in drug design for the improvement of bioactivity and selectivity. Wünsch and colleagues(141) designed 2,5-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octanes 21–23 by connecting conformationally flexible 2-hydroxyalkyl side chains to the piperazine ring of previously identified monocyclic piperazines 6 and 8 (Figure 10).(131) Bridged piperazines 21–23, synthesized by an improved Dieckmann-type cyclization protocol, show similar σ1 receptor affinity as the corresponding 2-(hydroxyethyl)piperazine 8. This configuration has a negligible effect on σ1 receptor affinity (e.g., stereoisomer 21 and 22 = 4.8 nM vs 6.9 nM). Expansion of the ethano bridge (22) to propano bridged homologue 23 with the same stereochemistry and substitution pattern results in comparative σ1 receptor affinity but significantly improves the σ1/σ2 selectivity (8- vs 177-fold).(141) Later, Martin et al.(142) reported a series of regioisomeric norbenzomorphans with varied σ receptor subtype selectivity, which depends upon the position of substituents (C7 vs C8) on its framework. Generally, C7-substituted norbenzomorphans (e.g., 24–25) preferentially bind at the σ1 receptor, whereas the corresponding C8-substituted analogues favor the σ2 receptor over the σ1 receptor. SARs indicate that the nitrogen atom of the norbenzomorphan scaffold may be decorated with benzyl (24), aryl sulfonamides (25), or carbamates groups (26), whereas the aryl ring may be adorned with morpholine (24), piperazine (25–26), or aryl groups. For example, the N-benzyl and N-sulfonamide regioisomers 24 and 25 substituted with morpholine and piperazine at the C7-position, respectively, follow the observed tendency toward σ1 receptor subtype selectivity (Ki(σ1) = 16.5 and 3.4 nM vs Ki(σ2) 562.3 and 48.0 nM, respectively).(142)
    To investigate the effects of reducing structural complexity of norbenzomorphans, Martin and colleagues(143) later generated a new collection of analogues substituted with tetrahydro-2-benzazepine, tetrahydroisoquinoline, or isoindoline by using a scaffold hopping strategy. Removal of the bridging methylene group in the norbenzomorphan 24 afforded a slightly more flexible tetrahydro-2-benzazepine 27 with better receptor affinity for both σ1 (Ki = 16.5 nM vs 6.1 nM, respectively) and σ2 (Ki = 562.3 nM vs 81 nM, respectively) receptors. Likewise, removing a methylene and ethylene group from 27 provides isoindoline 28 and tetrahydroisoquinoline 29, respectively, with better σ1 receptor affinity (Ki: 1.7–5.9 nM) and better selectivity (>19-fold). Wünsch’s group(144,145) discovered another series of tetrahydro-2-benzazepines by introduction of diverse linear or branched alk(en)yl substituents at the 2-position and benzyl groups at the 5-position. N-Cyclohexylmethyl (30: Ki = 2.4 nM), N-4-fluorobenzyl (31: Ki = 7.1 nM), and 5-(α-benzyloxy)benzyl (32: Ki = 9 nM) derivatives represent the most potent σ1 receptor ligands from this series with high selectivity over the σ2 receptor (Ki(σ2)/Ki(σ1) > 52). 30–32 all show poor affinity at the different binding sites of the NMDA receptor at 10 μM, but 31 has some degree of affinity to the dopamine D4 (91% inhibition), histamine H2 (59%), noradrenaline transporter (71%), and dopamine transporter (85%) at 1 μM concentration. 31 was well tolerated without inducing considerable side effects in the Irwin screen; nevertheless, 31 barely exhibited weak analgesic and cognition-enhancing activity, and no antidepressant-like effects in the forced swim test, the open field test, and the home cage activity test.(144)
    5.1.2.2. S1RA Analogues
    S1RA with a biaryl moiety and morpholine separately occupying the two hydrophobic binding pockets in Glennon’s model, is a highly selective σ1 receptor antagonist (Ki = 17 nM), which is currently undergoing phase 2 clinical trials for the treatment of oxaliplatin-induced neuropathic pain (Figure 11). As a back-up program, Esteve R&D(146) identified a new series of aryltriazoles and arylmethyltriazoles by employing a scaffold hopping approach around the arylpyrazole fragment of S1RA. The 3,4-dichorophenyltriazole 33 exhibits the most potent σ1 receptor affinity (Ki = 5 nM) with 67-fold selectivity over the σ2 receptor. Changing the piperidine of 33 for a morpholine group provides compound 34 with 9-fold less potency (Ki = 46 nM) but significantly improved selectivity (>218 ratio). A convergence was observed in the superposition of aryltriazole and arylmethyltriazole derivatives, and likewise the benzylic derivative 35 displayed comparable activities to its phenyl analogue 34. Morpholines 34 and 35 show lower hERG inhibition (IC50 > 10 μM) than piperidine 33 (1.7 μM) due to the reduction of either cLogP or pKa, two factors known to affect hERG activity (cLogP = 3.4 vs 4.6; pKa = 7.0 vs 9.1), suggesting a low incidence of cardiac toxicity.(147,148) Moreover, compounds 34 and 35 were found highly stable in human liver microsomes and highly permeable in Caco-2 cells.(146) Later, new S1RA derivatives based on the pyrazolo[3,4-d]pyrimidine scaffold in the primary hydrophobic pocket were designed on the basis of Glennon’s σ1 receptor pharmacophore model and their previous SAR studies.(149) 4-Acylaminopyrazolo[3,4-d]pyrimidine 36 exhibits nanomolar affinity (Ki = 51 nM) for the σ1 receptor and good selectivity over a panel of 66 receptors including the σ2 receptor (inhibition at 10 μM < 50%). It is noteworthy is that 36 has the potential drawback of instability at acidic pH values due to the instable amido linkage. The replacement of the 4-acylamino group in 36 with aromatic heterocycles was thus utilized for searching more stable alternatives.(150) The 4-(1-methylpyrazol-5-yl) derivative 37 showed no sign of degradation in solution at pH 2 or 7.4 and was later identified as the most selective σ1 receptor derivative over the σ2 receptor (Ki = 41 nM vs >1000 nM) and a wider panel of receptors. Moreover, 37 exhibits no significant inhibition for recombinant human cytochrome P450 (rhCYP) isoforms (1A2, 2C9, 2C19, 2D6, and 3A4; below 50% at 1 μM) and human hERG potassium channel (IC50 > 10 μM), suggesting low potential for drug–drug interactions and cardiac toxicity.(150)
    Additionally, compounds 34–37 by either intraperitoneal (ip 40 mg/kg) or oral (po 80 mg/kg) routes showed good activity in the formalin-induced pain model in mice, a classic model of acute and chronic pain, indicating their antagonistic nature.(146,149,150) Moreover, oral administration of 34–37 (80 mg/kg) was efficacious in reduction of mechanical hypersensitivity induced by capsaicin in mice (percentage reduction: 68%, 94%, 49%, and 43%, respectively) and dose-dependently inhibited both mechanical and thermal hyperalgesia in the partial sciatic nerve ligation (PSNL) mouse model, one of the most widely accepted neuropathic pain models (percentage reduction: 56%, 140%, 102%, and 46%, respectively). 35 was more efficacious than its homologue 34 in these two in vivo pain models, which may be ascribed to better solubility (>4 vs 0.17 mg/mL) and less lipophilicity (log P: 2.4 vs 2.9).(146)
    Zhang and colleagues(151−155) also developed several series of structurally diverse σ1 receptor antagonists based on modifications to the arylpyrazole moiety of S1RA (Figure 11). In 2014, they reported a series of 1-benzyl-3,4-dihydro-2(1H)-quinolinone derivatives derived from the 5-HT1A receptor agonist OPC-14523, which bound to the σ1 receptor at nanomolar concentrations (IC50 = 47 nM). Piperidine derivative 38 (Ki = 1.22 nM) and 4-methylpiperidine 39 (Ki = 0.77 nM) containing the same 4-fluorphenyl moiety exhibit the greatest potency and selectivity for σ1 receptor in the series (1066- and 1246-fold over σ2 receptor, respectively).(151) In the same year, a new series of 2-phenylpyrimidines as potent σ1 receptor antagonists was reported by using a three-dimensional (3D) pharmacophore model and virtual screening program.(152) Analogues 40 and 41 substituted separately, with a chlorine and fluorine group at the 4-position of the phenyl groups in 2-phenylpyrimidines, exhibit high affinity for the σ1 receptor (1.14 and 1.06 nM, respectively), and good σ1/σ2 selectivity (1165- and 1344-fold). Subsequently, cyclization of the 4- and 5-position of the pyrimidine scaffold of 40 provided two series of cycloalkane compounds based on 6,7-dihydro-5H-cyclopenta[d]pyrimidine and 5,6,7,8-tetrahydroquinazoline skeletons.(155) Cyclopenta[d]pyrimidine 42 and tetrahydroquinazoline 43 with 1-methylpiperidine and 4-chlorophenyl groups on both sides exert low nanomolar affinity for the σ1 receptor (Ki = 21.1 and 15.6 nM, respectively) and the high selectivity over the σ2 receptor (Ki > 2000 nM). Later, 2-phenyl-6-hydroxypyridazinones were designed by substituting ring bioisosteres of the pyrimidine moiety of 40.(154) 3,4-Dichloro substituted derivative 44 exhibits the lowest σ1 receptor affinity binding values (Ki = 1.4 nM) of the series and excellent selectivity over the σ2 receptor (1366-fold). Recently, Zhang group(153) also designed a series of phenyl-1,2-4-oxadiazole derivatives based on a hybridization approach of privileged fragments. The piperidinyl derivative 45, with 2,4-dichlorophenyl-1,2,4-oxadiazole, displays low nanomolar affinity (Ki = 0.28 nM) and high selectivity (587.1-fold) for the σ1 receptor.
    Because phenytoin can alter the binding of these compounds, 38–45 were identified as σ1 receptor antagonists. 40 and 44 also have good σ1 receptor selectivity profiles with no significant affinity (inhibition <50% at 1 μM) for other relevant pain receptors (e.g., μ-opioid, serotoninergic, H3, cannabinoid, NMDA receptors) and ion channels (voltage-gated sodium channel Nav 1.7 and TRPV-1 protein),(152,154) but compound 45 has moderate affinity for the H3 receptor (Ki = 23.2 nM). Moreover, 40 and 44 show excellent bioavailability (F = 75.1% and 87.5%, respectively) and a better safety profile compared to 41 in hERG channel assays (6.98 μM and 6.34 μM vs 1.54 μM) and acute toxicity assays ((LD50 > 2000 vs 884.5 mg/kg). On the basis of their good safety profiles, these compounds were thus further tested in various in vivo pain models. Compounds 38–40 and 43–45 are efficacious in attenuation of dose-dependent antinociceptive effects in the mouse formalin-induced pain model.(151−155) And 40 and 44–45 also dose-dependently inhibited mechanical allodynia and thermal hypersensitivity in the rat chronic constriction injury (CCI) model, a frequently used model of neuropathic pain. In addition, no motor impairments were observed in rotarod tests of 40 and 44 at antiallodynic doses.(154)
    Replacement the arylpyrazole moiety of S1RA with a biphenyl ring resulted in the identification of RC-33 (Figure 12) as a potent and promising σ1 receptor agonist (Ki = 0.9 nM) with potential in promoting NGF-induced neurite outgrowth in the PC12 cell line at low concentrations.(156) To enhance the σ1/σ2 selectivity of RC-33, a hydroxyl group was introduced at the α-position of the phenyl ring, leading to a slight decrease in σ1 receptor potency and selectivity (e.g., 46).(157) Later, a series of RC-33 monoaryl analogues was designed by replacing the biphenyl moiety with a naphthyl or phenyl ring for exploring the necessity of the biaryl group in S1RA analogues.(158) The 2-naphthalene derivative 47 exhibits comparable σ1 receptor affinity to RC-33 (Ki = 0.9 nM vs 1.5 nM), but lower selectivity (Ki(σ2)/Ki(σ1) = 33 vs 114), suggesting that the bulky naphthalene portion of 47 also fits well in the primary hydrophobic binding pocket of the σ1 receptor.(158) Further replacement of the monocyclic piperidine of 47 with the bicyclic granatane moiety and switching the linker from the 2-position of naphthalene to the 1-position provided 48 with similar σ1 receptor affinity (Ki = 1.5 nM vs 1.03 nM) and 10-fold improved selectivity over the σ2 receptor (ratio: 317 vs 33).(159)
    The Dukat group(160) found that a bulky 4-tert-butyl phenyl was similar to the naphthalene ring in 48 and considered as a key contributor to σ1 receptor binding (Figure 12). 48 was discovered by reevaluation of fenpropimorph, a so-called ‘‘super high-affinity” σ1 receptor ligand (Ki (pg) = 0.005 nM),(161) by using the ‘‘deconstruction–elaboration” approach. Removal of the entire branched methyl group on the linker and the morpholine ring of fenpropimorph (Ki = 17.3 nM) yielded compound 49 and 50 with similarly high σ1 receptor affinity binding values (Ki = 2.6 nM and 1.5 nM, respectively), suggesting that they were relatively less important. Although the morpholine O atom of fenpropimorph analogues (e.g., 49) is not important for σ1 receptor affinity, replacement with methylene leads to piperidine 50 with a dramatic decrease in σ receptor subtype selectivity as mentioned earlier in compounds 33 and 34.(160)N-(2-Morpholinoethyl)acetamide 51 with a 3,4-dichlorophenoxy group occupying in the primary binding pocket of σ1 receptor was identified by “in combo” screening combined with in silico and in vivo assessments.(162)51 shows high σ1 receptor affinity (Ki = 42 nM) and has 36-fold selectivity over the σ2 receptor. Ipsilateral local peripheral (10–300 mg/paw) and intrathecal (100 mg/rat) pretreatment with 51 led to a reduction on the flinching behavior in the formalin-induced nociception test, indicating 51 may be effective in treating inflammatory pain. 51 can block the intrathecal pronociceptive effect induced by PRE084 in the formalin test, suggesting the antinociceptive effect of 51 is mediated via σ1 receptor functionality.(162) Using the bioisostere replacement strategy, Romeo et al.(163) designed a set of 5-chlorobenzoxazole- and 5-chlorobenzothiazole-based derivatives containing an azepane ring. SAR studies indicate 5-chlorobenzoxazoles are more selective for σ1 receptor than 5-chlorobenzothiazoles (e.g., 52 vs 53). 5-Chlorobenzoxazole 52 and 5-chlorobenzothiazole 54 display the most potent σ1 receptor binding affinities of these derivatives with Ki values of 1.93 nM and 0.78 nM, respectively, but a dramatic decline in σ receptor subtype selectivity was observed in compound 54.
    5.1.2.3. Spirocyclic Sigma-1 Ligands
    In 2002, a conformationally restricted spirocyclic benzofuran 55 with an endocyclic amino moiety was reported by the Wünsch group(164) (Figure 13) as a highly potent σ1 receptor antagonist (Ki = 1.14 nM) with high σ1/σ2 selectivity (ratio: 1130), in which the benzofuran and benzyl moiety extended to the primary and secondary hydrophobic pocket of σ1 receptor, respectively. SAR studies indicate that substituents at the 4-position on the aromatic ring of the benzyl group tolerated small groups including fluoro, iodo, methoxy, and fluoroethyl.(165) In 2014, the Wünsch group designed pyridine analogues of 55 by bioisosteric replacement of CH-moieties in the benzene ring with an N-atom.(166) However, the four regioisomeric furopyridines (e.g., 56–57) show 7- to 12-fold poorer σ1 receptor affinity than the benzofuran analogue 55 (Ki = 4.9–10 nM), indicating that the reduced σ1 receptor affinity may be attributable to the reduced electron density of the pyridine ring rather than the direct interaction of the pyridine N-atom. Further expansion of the five-member furan ring in furopyridines (e.g., 57) to a six-membered ring provided spirocyclic pyranopyridines.(167)58 with a double bond in the pyran ring was identified as the most promising σ1 receptor ligand in the pyranopyridine class with a Ki value of 4.6 nM and a high selectivity over the σ2 receptor (>217-fold). The above results conclude that an electron deficient pyridine ring is less well tolerated by the σ1 receptor than the neutral benzene ring.(166,167) Hence, a series of 2-benzopyran σ1 receptor ligands were synthesized via an oxa-Pictet–Spengler reaction.(168) The benzyl substituted spirocyclic alcohol 59 achieved a low nanomolar σ1 receptor affinity (Ki = 20 nM) and good σ1/σ2 selectivity (Ki(σ2) > 1 μM). Further, a lipase-catalyzed kinetic resolution afforded enantiomerically pure 2-benzopyran derivatives, (R)-59 and (S)-59.(169) (R)-59 is 4.8-fold more potent than its enantiomer (S)-59 (Ki = 10 nM vs 48 nM) in σ1 receptor binding, and both show high selectivity over the σ2 receptor (Ki > 1000 nM), PCP/NMDA receptor (IC50 > 10000 nM), and the most structurally similar sterol-D8/D7-isomerases (IC50 > 1000 nM) in both yeast Yarrowia lipolytica and human HL-60 cells.
    Recently, another series of rigid spirocyclic σ1 receptor ligands based on the 2-benzopyran scaffold (e.g., 59) were synthesized by Wünsch and colleagues(170,171) via replacement of the spiro-piperidine with an exocyclic amino moiety (Figure 13). The benzyl group and spiro[benzopyran-1,1′-cyclohexane] scaffold separately occupy the two hydrophobic pockets of σ1 receptor. However, benzopyran trans-60 with the benzylamino moiety displays remarkable MOR affinity (Ki = 38 nM) and high MOR: σ1 receptor selectivity (14-fold). Excitingly, replacement of the benzyl moiety with a cyclohexylmethyl group shifts the receptor profile from MOR receptor selective ligands toward σ1 receptor selective ligands.(170) Transformation of the secondary cyclohexylmethylamines 61a and 61b (61a, Ki(σ1) = 19 nM, Ki(σ2) = 128 nM; 61b, Ki(σ1) = 5.8 nM, Ki(σ2) = 101 nM) into methylated tertiary amines 62a and 62b (62a, Ki(σ1) = 3.1 nM, Ki(σ2) = 154 nM; 62b, Ki(σ1) = 1.9 nM, Ki(σ2) = 12 nM) leads to improved σ1 receptor affinity. Although the cis-configured 3-methoxy-2-benzopyran cis-62b bearing a tertiary cyclohexylmethylamino group shows the best σ1 receptor affinity (Ki = 1.9 nM) in these series, the corresponding trans-configured isomer trans-62a shows higher σ1/σ2 selectivity (ratio: 49.7 vs 6.3). The secondary and tertiary cyclohexylmethylamines 61a, 61b, 62a, and 62b show no significant interaction with PCP/NMDA receptor up to a concentration of 1 μM. trans-61a and cis-61b also display no cytotoxicity and improved metabolic stability. Moreover, they show no inhibition against CYP enzymes CYP1A2, CYP2C9, CYP2C19, and CYP3A4 except modest CYP2D6 inhibition. Additionally, trans-62a and cis-62b do not interact with noradrenalin (NET), dopamine (DAT), and serotonin transporters (SET). However, cis-62b displays moderate displacement at a concentration of 1 μM toward α1A (68%), α2A (93%), 5-HT1A (60%), and 5-HT2B (62%) receptors. cis-62b was later confirmed as a σ1 receptor antagonist in a KCl-induced Ca2+ influx assay.(170)
    Amines trans-63a and cis-63b bearing a cyclohexylpiperazinyl moiety also show high σ1 affinity (Ki = 6.3 nM and 4.4 nM, respectively) with 10- to 50-fold selectivity over the σ2 receptor.(171) To increase metabolic stability, exchanging the 3-methoxy group in the 2-benzopyrans of trans-63a and cis-63b with a fluoroethyl side chain provided fluorinated compounds trans-64a and cis-64b. Although trans-64a and cis-64b decrease σ1 receptor affinity (Ki = 12 nM and 19 nM, respectively) and selectivity over the σ2 receptor (Ki = 45 nM and 432 nM, respectively),(171) they show good selectivity over a panel of other receptors, channels, and transporters, including opioid receptors, PCP/NMDA receptor, 5-HT2B receptor, hERG channel, NET, DAT, and SERT. However, they display high affinity to the ifenprodil binding site of GluN2B subunit containing NMDA receptors. In mice, trans-64a and cis-64b were confirmed to have stronger effects on capsaicin induced mechanical allodynia than that of the reference σ1 receptor antagonist BD-1063, suggestive of an antagonist profiles. The antiallodynic activity of trans-64a could only be partially reversed by the σ1 receptor agonist PRE084. However, the antiallodynic effect of its diastereomer cis-64b was observed probably due only to its interaction with the σ1 receptor.
    Multicomponent reactions (MCRs) are powerful synthetic strategies extensively employed to construct biologically interesting spiro compounds. In 2016, Ghandi et al.(172) described a one-pot synthesis of spirocyclic-2,6-diketopiperazines (Figure 14) as σ1 receptor selective ligands via two-step sequential, four-component Ugi multicomponent reaction/intramolecular N-amidation reactions by utilizing various acids, cyclic ketones, ethylglycinate hydrochloride, and cyclohexyl isocyanide. Compound 65 was identified with the best σ1 binding affinity and subtype selectivity of the series (Ki σ1 = 5.9 nM; σ2 = 563 nM). Later, a three component reaction of various amino acids, ketones, and isocyanides was reported by Majumdar and colleagues(173) to generate a library of various spiro-2,6-dioxopiperazines and spiro-2,6-pyrazine scaffolds with a piperidinyl group. The unsaturated spiro-2,6-dioxopyrazine 66 (UVM147) was identified as the most potent σ1 selective ligand (Ki = 8 nM) from this approach, screening over 50 different CNS receptors including GPCRs, ion channels, transporters, and enzymes through the psychoactive drug screening program (PDSP) funded by the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH). Importantly, 66 shows highly selective binding to σ1 over σ2 receptors (Ki σ2 = 696 nM) and several crucial CNS targets including 5-HT2B (Ki = 231 nM), 5-HT7 (Ki = 2765 nM), α2A (Ki = 3364 nM), D4 (Ki = 1283 nM), DAT (Ki = 2562 nM), H2 (Ki = 823 nM), and KOR (Ki = 1707 nM).(173) In addition, Lepovitz and Martin(174) synthesized bioactive azaspirocycles via a novel, efficient diversity-oriented synthesis (DOS) strategy that featured a tandem sequence involving imine formation and an aza-Sakurai reaction to form the spirocyclic system, and subsequently intramolecular Pictet–Spengler cyclization with formaldehyde to build tetrahydroisoquinoline rings. Azaspirocycle 67 shows a preference for the σ1 receptor (Ki = 8 nM) with moderate binding at σ2 (Ki = 152 nM) and α2A (Ki = 531 nM) receptor and weak affinity against a panel of approximately 44 other CNS proteins tested by the PDSP.(174)
    Beyond that, opening the spiro scaffold of potent spirocyclic σ1 receptor ligands represents an efficient structural modification strategy for development of novel σ1 receptor ligands with promising biopharmaceutical properties. For example, as shown in Figure 15, (±)-haloperidol (HP) and its derivatives 69–70 may be treated as the ring-opened arylpiperidine analogues of 59. HP is conventionally viewed as a dopamine D2 (Ki = 2.5 nM) and D3 (Ki = 6.1 nM) antagonist with antipsychotic effects but also is a σ1 receptor (Ki = 2.7 nM) antagonist and σ2 receptor (Ki = 17 nM) agonist with blockade of formalin-induced pain.(175) Further valproate esterification of HP metabolite II 68 (Figure 15) provided compound 69 [(±)-MRJF22] with preferential activity at the σ1 receptor over the σ2 receptor (Ki σ1 = 1.3 nM; Ki σ2 = 124 nM) and dopamine D2 and D3 receptors (Ki > 5000 nM).(176) On the other hand, methoxycarbonyl-1-phenyl-2-cyclopropylmethyl derivatives of HP (e.g., trans-(±)-70) display a double-digit nanomolar affinity for σ1 and σ2 receptors and low affinity toward D1 and D2 receptors.(177) The most promising compound, trans-(+)-70, has a low nanomolar affinity for σ1 receptors (Ki = 7 nM) and possesses the best selectivity ratio over σ2 receptors (Ki = 1837 nM) and more than 15 other receptors (Ki > 2500 nM), including opioid, dopaminergic, serotoninergic, and adrenergic receptors. trans-(+)-70 also has good chemical stability at both pH 1.3 and 7.4 (t1/2, 84 and 91 h, respectively), as well as enzymatic stability in human plasma (t1/2 = 65.2 h). An in vivo pharmacological evaluation evidenced that trans-(+)-70 (16–32 mg/kg, sc) did not enhance the antinociceptive effect of morphine. In contrast to the other three isomers which behaved as σ1 receptor antagonists, trans-(+)-70 exhibited a σ1 receptor agonist profile.(177)
    To reduce lipophilicity and enhance polarity, the Wünsch group(178,179) designed thiazole-based σ1 receptor ligands by bioisosterically replacing the thiophene ring and opening the pyran ring of spirocyclic thiophene derivatives 71–72 (Figure 15). Although spirocyclic thiophene 71 with an aryl substituent at the β-position shows considerably higher σ1 affinity than its regioisomer 72 with the aryl moiety at the α-position, their corresponding ring-opened thiazole derivatives 73 and 74, separately arylated at the C5- and C4-position, display conserved σ1 receptor affinity due to free rotation around the piperidine–thiazole bond.(178) However, the C5-arylated thiazole 73 shows higher σ1 receptor selectivity over σ2 receptors. The 5-pyridyl substituted thiazole derivatives 75 and 76 were the most promising candidates and exhibit low nanomolar affinity at the σ1 receptor (Ki = 1.3–1.9 nM), high σ1/σ2 selectivity (>1500-fold), and good ligand efficiency.(179) Additionally, Efange and colleagues(180) described a series of ring-opening spipethiane analogues by replacing the sulfur atom with a carbonyl (77), hydroxylmethenyl (78–79), or 3-bromobenzylamine (80) bridge (Figure 16). Although the σ1 receptor affinities of 77–80 were slightly lower than that of spipethiane, their good σ1 receptor selectivity over σ2 receptors was achieved.
    5.1.2.4. Polycyclic Sigma-1 Ligands
    Because the primary hydrophobic region of the σ1 receptor sterically tolerated a bulky group, including spirocyclic and polycyclic fragments, analogues with a substituted 1,4-dioxane ring were rationally designed and prepared by the Quaglia group.(181) As shown in Figure 17, 2,2-diphenyl-1,4-dioxane derivatives (e.g., 81) can be viewed as ANAVEX2-73 analogues which have a gem-diphenyl group on the 2-position of its tetrahydrofuran. Compound 81 was identified as the most promising compound in the series with the highest affinity (Ki = 7.37 nM) and good selectivity for σ1 over σ2 receptors and the NMDA receptor (Ki σ2 = 1000 nM, NMDA > 10 μM), and converged with the superimposed structure of haloperidol. In vivo, 81 had no antinociceptive effects at the highest tested dose (50 mg/kg) in the rodent hot plate assay when administrated alone, but it significantly increased morphine-induced (4 mg/kg) antinociceptive response until 60 min after its injection, suggesting a σ1 receptor antagonist profile of compound 81.(181) Later, a series of conformationally restricted 1,3-dioxanes bearing an axially oriented phenyl moiety in the 2-position was designed by mimicking the steric conformation of the benzomorphan scaffold of pentazocine and synthesized by two successive intramolecular transacetalization reactions.(182) The benzylamine 82b with equatorially oriented aminoethyl side chain shows 5-fold higher σ1 receptor affinity than its diastereomer 82a with axially oriented aminoethyl moiety (Ki = 5.9 nM vs 30 nM), representing the most potent σ1 receptor ligand of this series. However, benzylamine 82a displays slightly higher selectivity over the σ2 receptor than its diastereomer 82b (>33- vs 26-fold), and both benzylamines 82a and 82b display poor affinity for PCP/NMDA receptors.(182)
    Recently, Joubert et al.(183) designed a series of oxa- and aza- hexaxcyclododecylamines as σ1 receptor ligands based on their therapeutic potential for the development of CNS drugs. Although both the oxa- and aza-hexaxcyclododecylamine moieties are able to occupy the hydrophobic region of the σ1 receptor, the aza compounds are generally more favorable for σ1 receptor binding compared to their oxa counterparts (compound 83 vs 84). The aza-hexaxcyclododecylamine compound 83 shows moderate calcium flux inhibition (51% @ 100 μM), whereas the oxa-derivative 84 exhibits weak calcium flux inhibition (26% @ 100 μM), indicating a link between σ1 receptor activity and intracellular calcium levels.(183)
    Compounds 85–87 represent structurally unique polycyclic σ1 receptor ligands and lack many characterizations described by Glennon’s model.
